Text:
I have the following event listener:

    $(document).on('change', 'tr.transaction-desktop-top-row select.tax_rate', function(event) {
        var row = $(this).closest('tr[id^="dsk-top-"]');
        var num = parseInt(row.prop("id").match(/\\d+/g), 10);
        var eqTaxSelect = $('table#mob-tab-' + num).find('select.tax_rate').get();
        if(this.options[this.selectedIndex].value == 'customOption') {
            toggleField(this, this.nextElementSibling);
            toggleField($(eqTaxSelect), $(eqTaxSelect).nextElementSibling);
            this.selectedIndex = defaultTaxRate;
            eqTaxSelect.val(defaultTaxRate);
        } else {
            eqTaxSelect.val(this.value);
        }
        calculateForm(event);
    });

When this event is triggered, I go looking for the equivalent element (for a mobile layout) that is hidden, and I apply the action to both.

When I check `this` in `console.log()` i get the full element's html:

    <select name="tax_rate[]" class="tax_rate form-control" dir="rtl">
        <option value="customOption">[New Rate]</option>
        <option value="0">0.00</option>
        <option value="0.1000" selected="">10.00</option>
        <option value="0.3000">30.00</option>
    </select>

I am failing to capture the "mobile" element with my 

    var eqTaxSelect = $('table#mob-tab-' + num).find('select.tax_rate').get();

How to I change this assignment to retrieve the equivalent to the contents of `this` above but for my hidden element? I can find the element OK, but I stuck on how to access it in the same way as `this`. My code currently fails inside the toggle function due to 

    Uncaught TypeError: Cannot set property 'display' of undefined
 
for the `eqTaxSelect` call. Here's my toggle function

    function toggleField(hideObj, showObj) {
        hideObj.style.display = 'none';
        showObj.style.display = 'inline';
        showObj.focus();
    }

So
   
    toggleField(this, this.nextElementSibling);   <-- THIS WORKS
    toggleField($(eqTaxSelect), $(eqTaxSelect).nextElementSibling); <-- FAILS

Thanks!

I get an element from my layout with this command:

    var eqTaxSelect = $('table#mob-tab-' + num).find('select.tax_rate').get();

I then try to toggle it:

    toggleField($(eqTaxSelect), $(eqTaxSelect).nextElementSibling); <-- FAILS

    function toggleField(hideObj, showObj) {
        hideObj.style.display = 'none';     <-- FAILS HERE
        showObj.style.display = 'inline';
        showObj.focus();
    }


with:

    Uncaught TypeError: Cannot set property 'display' of undefined

What am I doing wrong when assigning the element to my variable? This function works for `this` inside click event listeners for example.
Thanks!

I get an element from my layout with this command: var eqTaxSelect = $('table#mob-tab-' + num).find('select.tax_rate').get(); I then try to toggle it: toggleField($(eqTaxSelect), $(eqTaxSelect).nextElementSibling); <-- FAILS function toggleField(hideObj, showObj) { hideObj.style.display = 'none'; <-- FAILS HERE showObj.style.display = 'inline'; showObj.focus(); } with: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot set property 'display' of undefined What am I doing wrong when assigning the element to my variable? This function works for `this` inside click event listeners for example. Thanks! The HTML I am toggling came from this forum, esentially a select with a hidden input so new entries can be added as well as using an entry from the options list. I am mirroring two elements like these on the page
%

**EDIT:** Thanks for the help. To clarify further, the above code is inside of an event listener like so: $(document).on('change', 'tr.transaction-desktop-top-row select.tax_rate', function(event) { var row = $(this).closest('tr[id^="dsk-top-"]'); var num = parseInt(row.prop("id").match(/\\d+/g), 10); var eqTaxSelect = $('table#mob-tab-' + num).find('select.tax_rate').get(); console.log(this); console.log(eqTaxSelect); if(this.options[this.selectedIndex].value == 'customOption') { toggleField(this, this.nextElementSibling); <-- THIS WORKS toggleField(eqTaxSelect, eqTaxSelect.nextElementSibling); <-- THIS FAILS this.selectedIndex = defaultTaxRate; $(eqTaxSelect).val(defaultTaxRate); } else { $(eqTaxSelect).val(this.value); } calculateForm(event); }); In `console.log()`, `this` contains: In `console.log()`, `eqTaxSelect` contains: [select.tax_rate.form-control]0: select.tax_rate.form-controllength: 1__proto__: Array[0] single:1652 [select.tax_rate.form-control]

I get an element from my layout with this command:

    var eqTaxSelect = $('table#mob-tab-' + num).find('select.tax_rate').get();

I then try to toggle it:

    toggleField($(eqTaxSelect), $(eqTaxSelect).nextElementSibling); <-- FAILS

    function toggleField(hideObj, showObj) {
        hideObj.style.display = 'none';     <-- FAILS HERE
        showObj.style.display = 'inline';
        showObj.focus();
    }


with:

    Uncaught TypeError: Cannot set property 'display' of undefined

What am I doing wrong when assigning the element to my variable? This function works for `this` inside click event listeners for example.
Thanks!

The HTML I am toggling came from this forum, esentially a select with a hidden input so new entries can be added as well as using an entry from the options list. 

**EDIT:** 
Thanks for the help. To clarify further, the above code is inside of an event listener like so:

    $(document).on('change', 'tr.transaction-desktop-top-row select.tax_rate', function(event) {

        var row = $(this).closest('tr[id^="dsk-top-"]');
        var num = parseInt(row.prop("id").match(/\\d+/g), 10);
        var eqTaxSelect = $('table#mob-tab-' + num).find('select.tax_rate').get();

    console.log(this);
    console.log(eqTaxSelect);

         if(this.options[this.selectedIndex].value == 'customOption') {
             toggleField(this, this.nextElementSibling);   <-- THIS WORKS
             toggleField(eqTaxSelect, eqTaxSelect.nextElementSibling);  <-- THIS FAILS
             this.selectedIndex = defaultTaxRate;
             $(eqTaxSelect).val(defaultTaxRate);
         } else {
             $(eqTaxSelect).val(this.value);
         }
         calculateForm(event);
    });

In `console.log()`, `this` contains:

     <select name="tax_rate[]" class="tax_rate form-control" dir="rtl" style="display: none;">
         <option value="customOption">[New Rate]</option>
         <option value="0">0.00</option>
         <option value="0.1000" selected="">10.00</option>
         <option value="0.3000">30.00</option>
         <option value="0.5000">50.00</option>
     </select>

In `console.log()`, `eqTaxSelect` contains:

     [select.tax_rate.form-control]0: select.tax_rate.form-controllength: 1__proto__: Array[0]
      single:1652 [select.tax_rate.form-control]

[JSFIDDLE here][1]. I am trying to mirror DESKTOP 1 to MOBILE 1 elements (same for #2) in the fiddle. The error is shown to be the same in console log.

Got to DESKTOP 1 and select NEW RATE from the list. Have the console opened to see the issue. Thanks!

        showObj.focus();

with:

What am I doing wrong when assigning the element to my variable? This function works for `this` inside click event listeners for example.
Thanks!

The HTML I am toggling came from this forum, esentially a select with a hidden input so new entries can be added as well as using an entry from the options list.
